Innsyoutei Review | Bon Appetit









































Close Menu IconLoginRecipesCookingCultureShoppingRestaurantsBA MarketVideosPodcastSubscribe to our newsletterSign UpPrivacy and user agreementMain Navigation IconBA LogoBon appetitLogintokyoInnsyouteiReconsider what you think you know about tofu.FacebookPinterestTwitterEmailPhoto by Xavier Girard Lachaîne“Eating at Innsyoutei is a serene, almost spa-like experience: You leave your shoes at the door and are whisked into a hushed dining room with floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking the maple trees of Ueno Park. You sit cross-legged on thin, flat zabuton (floor cushions) at a very low table, and the servers wear traditional kimonos and kneel beside you. The tofu and yuba tasting menu is incredible: Imagine many courses of fresh tofus (including a matcha-infused variety with a springy texture), miso soup with rich seaweed and bracing shiso, and donabe with tea-soaked rice, crispy little fishes, and roe. That last dish was truly one of our favorite things we ate in Tokyo—subtle but so heartwarming.”—Jen Pelka of The Riddler and Charles Billies of Souvla, both in San FranciscoExplore City GuidesAtlantaAustinBostonCharlestonChicagoCopenhagenLas VegasLondonLos AngelesMexico CityMiamiMontrealNew OrleansNew YorkParisPhiladelphiaPortlandSan FranciscoSeattleTokyoTorontoVancouverWashington, D.C.GET THE MAGAZINEBA LogoBon appetitSUBSCRIBESign up for Updates on the Bon AppétitCity GuidesSign UpWill be used in accordance with our user agreement and privacy policyBA LogoBon appetitSubscription FAQsMastheadNewsletter SignupAccessibility HelpRSS FeedsSite MapCondé Nast StoreCareersBon Appétit Media KitDo Not Sell My Personal InformationCondé NastFood Innovation Group: Bon Appétit and Epicurious© 2022 Condé Nast.
